Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I was halfway down the hallway, laptop bag slung over my shoulder, when I saw the group of neighbors gathered in the lobby. The building manager waved me over, her smile tight. “We’re just waiting for you to start,” she said. I knew what this was about—the noise complaint that had everyone on edge. As a neighbor, I was expected to be friendly, to listen, to help smooth things over. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, and I glanced at the screen: urgent Slack messages from my team. The production outage was still unresolved, and the root cause was a bug I’d introduced. Users were locked out, and the pressure to fix it was mounting by the minute. I could feel my heart pounding, torn between the expectation to be present and polite with my neighbors and the desperate need to get back upstairs and troubleshoot. My mind raced, guilt and anxiety twisting together as I tried to figure out how I could possibly meet both demands.
